channel.title: Ryan Bonhardt
channel.description: I want to make education more effective.

item.title: Home
item.content:encoded:
I want to make education more effective.

I am the founder of MASSIVE Academy and Online Director for Miles 2 Give. As you can see above I have a strong passion for improving education, specifically online education and have a dream that one day every one will have the chance to learn how to code and build things online.  

I write here, on medium, and on the MASSIVE Academy blog.

You're cool. Want to receive updates of my writings on online education and learning?

You're awesome.  Only the coolest stuff on the way. 

And now check out some of my most recent posts:

Blog
Get Off Your A** And Create Something
about 4 months ago
How To Increase MOOC Completion Rates
about 4 months ago
Learning to Learn: Don't Learn. Do.
about 4 months ago
How To Go From Zero To Hero: Your First Website
about 4 months ago

More About Me

During college I decided to avoid "Corporate America", work my dream jobs and live life as I wanted to. In the beginning it was rough and I STRUGGLED….but then I discovered simple tricks to promote myself and how to learn skills rapidly. Since then I’ve founded MASSIVE Academy, helped found a non-profit running across the USA for Sarcoma cancer research, lived in 10 cities, been a white water river guide, surfed across Latin America, and advised multiple small businesses. My goal is to always love what I’m doing and do what I love - to learn something new and add value daily.

“I get up every morning determined to both change the world and have one hell of a good time.  Sometimes this makes planning my day difficult. – E. B. White"

MASSIVE Academy

At MASSIVE Academy we want to better education and give people the ability to make money as they follow their passion. To do this we teach courses on web development, self branding, growth hacking and business testing.  On the side of "better education" we believe in learning by doing and project-based learning.  All of our courses follow a skill acquisition model where the students have a clear cut goal that they will achieve by completing a project.  We don't believe in tests and subjective assessments, but creating and objective measurements of learning.

 

Miles 2 Give

Miles 2 Give is a 501c3 Non-Profit organization that raises funding for sarcoma cancer research by running unprecedented team routes worldwide. We believe we are in a Generation Of A Cure. This 2013 tour our road team ran from San Francisco, CA to Ocean City, MD raising over $103,000 for research.  For the next tour I am excited to announce that we have partnered with Huntsman Cancer Institute to give them direct distribution for research of all funds raised and that they will match every day we raise with one of their own.  AMAZING.

item.title: Standards
item.content:encoded:
Rules are externally applied and are not usually adopted.  Standards are internally owned.  They're what you live by. Create them and own them.

-- Coach K at Chik-Fil-A Leadership Conference  May 2013

I dubbed the year of 2013 the year to change - myself first and then other changes will naturally follow.  I had initial positive gains, but hit a plateau of improvement in March and couldn't figure out why.  Then, at the Chik-Fil-A leadercast Coach K hit me with the above quote as he was discussing how he helped lead the 2012 USA Men's Basketball Team on their way to Olympic Gold.  I had been creating rules for myself to follow - which are meant to be broken right?  Not standards that I internally owned.  These are the standards I currently aim to own.  I'm sure they'll change.

  1. Stop and simplify: 
    • Start with a clean slate – I don't work clean, but it started clean – if something is on your mind, take time to write it down and solve it. --David Allen
    • Prioritize. Maximum 3 goals at a time.  What are your enabling factors? -- Condoleeza Rice
    • less is MORE
  2. DON'T DABBLE. Draw boundaries and necessary endings.  Then dive in.  --Henry Cloud
  3. Fear nothing and go at it with confidence  --50th Law
  4. NOW. Enjoy now. Do it now.
  5. Be honest with yourself.
  6. PLAY and do what I love

item.title: Current Projects
item.content:encoded:
1. Miles 2 Give

    Miles 2 Give is a 501c3 non-profit organization that raises funding for Sarcoma cancer research through cross country ultra running.  We are a small 4 man team so I concentrate on big media wins and creating effective systems online for us to create personal relationships with our fans and followers.

  2. Quick Decisions, Long Relationships

    I'm writing a book on how to use startup principles in the non-profit sector and your everyday work or life to increase productivity and create lasting relationships; all backed by real-world examples we used at Miles 2 Give to create a six-figure non-profit in less than 6 months.

  3. Massive Academy

    We're working to bring a world-class program to Tallahassee to mentor startups and equip individuals with the skill-set it takes to be successful in the startup landscape.

  4. Startup Engineering

    A brilliant class hosted on CourseEra.org from Stanford University for free.  100,000+ students are enrolled globally.  Students must create an HTML5 app, and promote it to gain crowdfunding and social shares.  Students in different categories that get the most funding via bitcoin and the most twitter shares could get startup interest and job offers.

Past Projects

  • Raised over $100,000 for Sarcoma Cancer Research during our 6-month inaugural run for Miles 2 Give
  • Living in Brazil for 2 summers traveling and playing soccer across nation with Atletico Paranaense juveniles 
  • Certified Whitewater River Guide at US Whitewater Center in Charlotte, NC
  • Modeled and Acted in NYC, Atlanta, and LA
  • Surfed, traveled, and other fun stuff across Latin America including building schools, churches, and living minimal for a month without electricity in jungle in southeastern tip of the Osa Peninsula (Costa Rica). Most rewarding period of my life.

item.title: Learning Now
item.content:encoded:
He wrote that as part of his profession of getting to know himself he found such “boundless depths and variety that [his] apprenticeship bears no other fruit than to make me know much there remains to learn.”

--Ryan Holliday referring to Montaigne

  • Ruby On Rails

    • Courses / Materials: One Month Rails, Ruby On Rails Tutorial, Treehouse, Codecademy, Ruby Monk
    • Why? To create things of value available to the masses for greater good. Also because everyone should be able to code now.  And to eventually become involved in the education technology sector with startups and help reform our education system and the way people learn.

 

  • The Media Landscape, how to gain big wins, and hacking initial growth

    • This is 80% of my efforts with Miles 2 Give and will determine the success of our inaugural event of running across the USA.
    • Resources: Trust Me I'm Lying and GrowHack.com

 

  • The Lean Building of startups and testing business ideas efficiently

    • Readings: The Lean Startup
    • Courses: Startup Engineering at Stanford on CourseEra.com

 

  • Sales

    • Everything in life is about sales: promotion of your self, making money to live etc. To me learning sales means learning to build a relationships and identifying "the value" people desire. This will always be on my learning list.
    • Class taking: Validation: Start a company without spending another dollar (or needing a tech co-founder

 

What I want to learn later

  • Spanish: I'm semi-fluent in it currently, and will achieve fluency before I take my next trip to a Spanish speaking country.  After fluency I will work through other latin-based language and continue to evolve my language learning process.  Two systems I currently use for learning languages: duolingo.com, and Tim Ferriss's language-learning practices.
  • Mixed Martial Arts: Other than physical benefits I want to work on being present and feel as though this and Meditation/Yoga are the best areas of practice for this.

item.title: Skills
item.content:encoded:
Coding:

  • Ruby – codeacademy and ruby monk profiles
  • Wordpress and ecommerce development : miles2give.org, staffspecials.com
  • Facebook pages and applications: miles2give FB store, Garnet and Gold Tallahassee

Learning new skills effectively:

I was always gifted in school, as valedictorian and then summa cum laude in college with (what I would consider minimal effort), as well as >95% percentile in standardized tests: gmat, act, fcat.  I did this by establishing systems which were unbeknownst to me until I started reading the 4-Hour series and Moonwalking With Einstein.  I have since identified these systems and continued to refine them through language-learning, and teaching myself web development.  I place a strong emphasis on creating wins early and one-pagers or what we would consider cheat sheets.

  • read more: Tim Ferris presentation,

Project Management and simplifying systems

  • Miles 2 Give: head of operations and organization of a 4-man team that has collected $90,000+ in first 6 months while being featured in 30+ publications and 10+ tv networks
  • I also consult with companies across Northwest Florida on how to simplify their operations through prioritizing and simplifying their goals and online applications that help them automate certain aspects of their operations.

item.title: Good Reads
item.content:encoded:
Books that have changed my life

  • Four Hour Workweek by Tim Ferriss: This was the first book that 1) That I willingly read and 2) summarized and made attainable all the thoughts I was having in college.  AKA having fun and doing what I want for a living. Warning: powerful book; handle with care. Topics: BUSINESS, PRODUCTIVITY, PHILOSOPHY
  • First 20 Hours by Josh Kaufman: Reading this now.  So far...AMAZING.  Simplifies the acceleration of skill acquisition.  Makes me feel like a nerdy Superman. Topics: LEARNING, PRODUCTIVITY
  • Ender's Game by Orson Scott Card: Sci-Fi book.  If you like Hunger Games you will love this book.  Also if you every felt alienated as a child for being smart (all you academic teamers like me) you will resonate with Ender on his journey. Topics: FICTION, PHILOSOPHY
  • Four-Hour Chef by Tim Ferriss: Another book on meta-learning.  Tim Ferriss does a great job in all his writings of simplifying, entertaining, and inspiring you to get your ass out there and do it.  The organized chronicles of a walking science experiment. Topics: LEARNING
  • Hacking Your Education by Dale J Stephens: The final kick in the arse to this site being created.  If you are any where from 18-25, questioning what you're doing, questioning the education system, or debating going back to school - hell anybody that's not perfectly happy with their current situation - read it.  Also follow his blog - Peter Thiel is banking on him. Topics: LEARNING, PHILOSOPHY, PRODUCTIVITY, SELF-ADVANCEMENT

[hr]

Startup Growth and Growth Hacking

Growth Hacking: Lean Marketing For Startups by Mattan Griffel: This is probably the most complete guide I've seen on growth hacking so far.

Appsumo's Rational Growth Manual: Geared around thinking analytically about your growth through data and conversions.

Noah Kagan's Rogue Marketing Strategy: If you know Noah then know this will be good.  One of first employees at Facebook and Mint; and now runs his own multi-million dollar business.

Guerrilla Influence Formula by Tyler Tervooren: I haven't had time to read this yet, but it was referred to me by somebody I respect in marketing and has worked with multiple Bestselling Authors and Startups.

Gaining Media and PR

Trust Me I'm Lying by Ryan Holliday: He does an amazing job breaking down the national media/blog circus and gives you the groundwork of how to break on the scene.  His reading list is also a wonder of sorts.

Next In Line

Choose Yourself by James Altucher: Recommended by Ryan Holiday

Personal MBA by Josh Kauffman: Here's an excerpt from Seth Godin (if you don't know who Seth Godin is push over that rock) -> "File this book under NO EXCUSES. After you've read it, you won't be open to people telling you that you're not smart enough, not insightful enough, or not learned enough to do work that matters. Josh takes you on a worthwhile tour of the key ideas in business."

To Sell is Human by Daniel Pink: "Excellent…radical, surprising, and undeniably true." —Harvard Business Review Blog

Art of Learning by Josh Waitzkin: After dominating the scholastic chess world for ten years, Waitzkin expanded his horizons, taking on the martial art Tai Chi Chuan and ultimately earning the title of World Champion. How was he able to reach the pinnacle of two disciplines that on the surface seem so different? "I've come to realize that what I am best at is not Tai Chi, and it is not chess," he says. "What I am best at is the art of learning."

Moonwalking with Einstein by Josh Foer: An instant bestseller that is poised to become a classic, Moonwalking with Einstein recounts Joshua Foer's yearlong quest to improve his memory under the tutelage of top "mental athletes."

 

That's all I can think of for now.  More to come...

Like This Page? Why Not Share It?

item.title: Quickie About Me
item.content:encoded:
"I get up every morning determined to both change the world and have one hell of a good time.  Sometimes this makes planning my day difficult. --E. B. White

I use this blog to document and retain my adventures in learning.

Fun version...

Hi, I’m Ryan Bonhardt and during college I decided to avoid Corporate America, work my dream jobs and live life as I wanted to. In the beginning it was rough and I STRUGGLED....but then I discovered simple tricks to promote myself and get the "jobs" I wanted. Since then I've helped found a non-profit running across the USA for Sarcoma cancer research, lived in 10 cities, been a white water river guide, and advised multiple small businesses. I want to share these tricks and my adventures with you... and my future self

Serious version...

I don’t like the narcissistic and nostalgic nature of the about section so I’ll keep it more aimed towards now and moving forward. My goal is to always love what I’m doing and do what I love.  To learn something new (this video will change how you learn and your life) and add value daily.  Currently I have a strong interest in web-app development and effective learning methods. Through applications we can instantly deliver a sophisticated system of value to millions and what better capital to improve than learning capital.  Further, I want to be a contributing member of a startup in the education technology revolution that is beginning right now.  Examples: duolingo, memrise, etc.

Further Reading: Why Software is Eating the World

Learn More About Me

  • Standards
  • Goals
  • Skills
  • Projects: Past and Present
  • Learning: Now and Future

item.title: Get Off Your A** And Create Something
item.content:encoded: I just posted a medium article on the difference between those that do and those that don't. Its a look into the creative process, what leads to the creation of things, what hinders the creative process and how to get past those road bumps in the process.  I had a good time writing it, plus I think you're cool so you should read it.  Read it here

item.dc:creator: rbonhardt@gmail.com

item.title: Learning to Learn: Don't Learn. Do.
item.content:encoded:
"I realized that becoming a master of karate was not about learning 4,000 moves but about doing just a handful of moves 4,000 times." -- Chet Holmes

So you have this "new thing" you want to learn how to do.  And you don't know how to learn it so you look on google and read some forums and you're overwhelmed with all the information.  You have this mountain in front of you that you want to conquer and a confusing "road map" to do so.

"Well let's get a better road map."  You google and search Amazon for the best beginner guides or websites on the subject - in our case mountain.  You then go out and buy one or a couple of the currently "cool and popular" learning materials or subscribe to one of the hip online courses on the subject.  You dive in for a couple days, learning all the basics and eventually your initial excitement and motivation fizzles and you're left feeling like you have so much more to learn, you've achieved very little, and you stop.  You repeat this process with the next "new skill" you want to learn.

Rinse and repeat until you don't want to rinse or repeat anymore.

"That's it I'll never learn something new."

[Enter my young naive self] "But Ryan that's stupid!  If I was going to climb a mountain I'd just start climbing or I'd grab a guide and he'd take my giddy ass up the hill."

YESS EXACTLY!!!!

You wouldn't sit around eating twinkies staring at your impending mountain foe.  YOU'D START SCALING THAT MOUNTAIN!!

If you hired a guide he wouldn't sit you down at base camp and take you through hours of hiking, fire building, and what ever other hiking related exercises you need.  He'd get you trekking up the mountain and teach you as you go.  And if he didn't then you'd move on to the next jolly bearded guide (yes all hikers are jolly and bearded and part hipster) down the road.

*NOTE* "Well Ryan actually if I were to scale [insert dangerous mountain] I'd want all those exercises and training before I took on that danger." We're NOT scaling everest here - remember we're beginning to learn how to climb mountains not achieving expert Sherpa status.

YOU didn't LEARN TO WALK by READING BOOKS.  You tried multiple times, fell down, got back up, and eventually stumbled your diaper draped fat rolls of legs into the loving arms of your mom or dad.  So when did we decide we need to dot all our I's and cross our T's before we learned a new skill or took on a new challenge?

My theory is we learned it somewhere along our 12+ years of education between the myriad of tests.  We became so accustomed to making sure we knew everything and would get that A that we took that into all aspects of learning. (*NOTE* Acquire, don't just learn - read The First 20 Hours for more on this).

Also, WE'RE SCARED OF FAILING - naturally.  And the best way to make sure we don't fail (just like in school) is to make sure we have all the bases covered and know everything before even taking our first step.  Or eventually not taking the first step at all. Sounds exhausting right?  Well it is.

By learning all the principles before even trying you inherently stacks the odds against you:

1. We all only have so much excitement and motivation about a new subject until it runs out.  And if you don't create wins and progress in the beginning, the two quickly dwindle.  Think of  a battery reloading.

2. By trying to "learn it all" in the beginning you are putting so much added pressure and exhaustion on yourself.  You're only going to use about 20% on a regular basis of all the fundamentals you'll learn.  Well what happens with the remaining 80%? It's intimidating you.  It stays in the back of your mind and you constantly wonder when you're going to need to use it.

3. And by throwing the kitchen sink at yourself in the beginning you realize how little you actually know on the subject.  We don't want to realize that till later when we can balance it with what we've already learned/done and how far we've come in our new venture.  Ignorance is bliss - especially in the case of acquiring or learning a new skill.

So next time you are trying to learn something new or you're trying to teach a group of newbies here is my advice to you...wait for it...

JUUUUST DOOOOO ITTTTTT (props to Nike).  Learn by doing. And here's some pointers along the way...

1. Come up with a project: Why are you or they learning it? 

For me I'm currently learning web (mobile-view) application development.  The reason I'm doing this is because I want to be able to build applications (quick lesson: facebook, twitter, hulu are web applications; your pizza restaurant down the street has a website).  So my project is building my first web application.  By having a project you have a gauge to judge your progress, you have an endpoint to strive for (always a key to accomplishing your goals) and you are working on something you care about - which all 3 will decrease your chances of giving up. Some examples of different projects for different skills:

Language learning - have a 10 minute conversation with a native speaker

Surfing - be able to get up and ride all the way in (or until you choose to bail) at least 3 times in a session.

Chess - getting ranked to a certain level.  You can play on line to do this.

Musical instrument - learn to play a certain song.  (Axis of Awesome - so many songs with only 4 chords)

2. Buy, rent, or somehow get ahold of the 1-3 best sources on the subject: book, guide, video, website

First you will need to skim these to see where to begin (and any tools you made need) and identify the most common terms/themes amongst them so that you know what you will need to revisit later as you learn.  At this point start your project.  The most ideal, and what I always look for, is for one of the guides to be along the lines of your project.  For example if you were wanting to learn ruby on rails development there is Hartl's Ruby on Rails Tutorial in which he walks you through how to build a twitter-like application.

In other words find a guide or course that walks you through a project of its own. It will be similar enough and you'll learn enough in the process so that you can tweak that project to be your own. This creates early wins - you're actually creating something - and helps you maintain your excitement and interest in the subject.  Progress

3. When further reading is required or your confused consult the other sources you grabbed

When you're going through that guide or course there will be points where you might need some guidance, further reading on the topic, and/or have questions.  This is when you return to the other guides or online sites to dig deeper about that certain subject or topic.  Don't waste your time learning each topic until you need to.  This eliminates a lot "learning and attentive time waste."

4. Quantity over quality.  Do it. Do it. And do it some more

Learning by doing.  At each new subskill, chapter, or roadblock you're going to want to analyze and cover all the basics.  In other words you're going to want to make everything perfect - DON'T.  Just do it.  Go at it naively.  Its quantity over quality.  You make your code look better, the music sound crisper, the vase your shaping more perfect on your next try.  You learn by doing.

In The First 20 Hours Josh Kaufman tells a story about a pottery class that was split into 2 groups.  One group was told that they'd be graded on how many pieces of pottery they made and the other half on how beautiful one piece was.  The "quantity" group quickly set out making piece after piece.  The "quality" group tried to create that perfect piece.  Then when it was time at the end of the course for everyone to be graded consistently the most beautiful pieces of pottery belonged to pupils from "quality" group.

It's because they could only fail by not doing.  As you continuously do something you develop and notice new subtleties that work and continue to refine your process.  So don't be worried to fail.  Don't aim to get it right the first time.  Just do it.  Fail miserably multiple times.  Eventually you will succeed.

Seinfeld practices this through his comedy-writing.

TO-DO

So go on. Do. Fail. Do. Roadblock. Find answer. Do. Fail. Learn. Succeed.

And enjoy it :)

P.S. What skill are you learning or teaching right now?

P.P.S. You're cool. Want to receive updates of my super awesome writings on online education and learning?

You're awesome.  Only the coolest stuff on the way.
item.dc:creator: rbonhardt@gmail.com

item.title: How To Go From Zero To Hero: Your First Website
item.content:encoded:
It boggles my mind that more people don't make a conscious effort to learn how to write and code. --Dale J. Stephens

Have you always wondered about this mystical world of websites and how to make them?

Or thought it would be too hard to learn?

Or just don’t know where to start?

Well don’t worry, soon (less than 20 hours) you will laugh in the face of CSS and HTML and be on the way to learning bigger and better things.

The goal of this article is to take a person completely new to building websites (HTML and CSS) and to have their first site up in less  a day.  From their you will have the groundwork and fundamentals to continue trying new things and building any site you want.

This is the article I wish I had when I decided learn web programming 4 years ago.  I searched the internet for the fastest way to learn html, css, and javascript.  Instead what I should have done is scoured the internet for skill acquisition models and meta-learning principles.  From my findings my plan would have been reversed.

Instead of taking the time to learn each – html, css, and javascript – in their entirety I would have attacked it along the guidelines of “The First 20 Hours”.  So here’s to you, person excited and scared to jump into the world of  front-end web development:

Note: In case you're confused, front-end is everything you see as a visitor to the site (HTML is the structure, CSS is the style).  The more complicated stuff is the back-end - stuff behind the scenes - which is the functionality.  For now don't worry about any of that.

First off, what do you want to be able to do? Be specific.

 Answer this question so you have a measuring stick and goal in mind.  With this goal you will be more inclined to work towards it and know when you have achieved it.

Are you trying to learn because you have a business idea and want to test it? 

If its just one item (ebook idea, service, ecourse) then use unbounce or instapage to create your site (which is actually just a page) – no coding necessary ; you’d just be wasting hours when you could skip to testing your business idea.  To accept payments on those sites you can use the simple, new and fastly-growing gumroad (great for digital goods, not physical….yet), the old standard paypal or one of my favorites wepay.

But if you’re in this category STOP. 

Here’s a hint on how to avoid losing $15,000 on your first business idea like I did.  TEST YOUR IDEA FIRST.  Before you jump in creating a website, buying product, business cards, tshirts, trademarks, web hosting and taking hours to set up your business. STOP

Take a couple dollars and couple hours and check out one or two of the following:

  1. How to Create a Million-Dollar Business This Weekend: a quick blog post that will get you in the mindset of testing your idea first.
  2. How to Make your First Dollar: course from the guys at AppSumo on how to test your business ideas and get your first dollar.  QUALITY.  If you don't agree you get your money refunded
  3. Make your First Dollar: a hyphenated course from above on Skillshare.  Quick and Easy, but powerful.
  4. The $100 Startup
  5. Or the automating section of Four Hour Workweek.

You will learn how to test your ideas the right way before you waste money. You can send me a thank you card later.

Do you want to start a blog or virtual site to promote yourself?

Here are some great blogging platforms that require no coding knowledge (in the order I recommend): wordpress.com, weebly, and squarespace.

Do you want to build and design websites for clients?

The first question from here is what type of functionality are they going to need.

If it’s a basic site with just content and minimal functionality like a form then I recommend going with weebly or squarespace and building the site.  You can find plugins from 3rd party services and use weebly’s custom html and css boxes to add those plugins in.  For example: for a form you can create one in wufoo and then add it in weebly.

If your client’s site is going to need more functionality (bells and whistles) then lets learn some CSS and HTML.  More to come on that….

Do you want to one day be able to build sites from scratch and/or move on to actual web application development?

Well then…welcome to the fun stuff and obviously you will have to learn HTML and CSS.

So we begin...

Our lovable project is going to be our first website

Remember this is just your first site and you’re acquiring the skills of front-end web development in the fastest way possible.  So you’re going to jump in over your head, take shortcuts, experiment, and create fast feedback loops (all of these ideas come from The First 20 Hours).  The cool thing is that web development is a perfect environment for all the above.

A set of subskills

Barebones front-end web development is composed of 3 subskills: design, css, and html.  I won’t hit on design here, but less is more; design minimal.

In terms of CSS and HTML here are some how-to guides I suggest you purchase and/or bookmark for reference while you’re building your first site:

  • Head First HTML and CSS
  • w3schools.com
  • css-tricks.com

The most important principles you’ll need to hone (in my humble opinion of course) are:

  1. HTML vs. CSS
    1. quick section in Head First
  2. Divs, IDs, Classes
    1. quick section in Head First
    2. http://css-tricks.com/the-difference-between-id-and-class/
  3. The box model: 2 quick lessons
    1. css tricks: http://css-tricks.com/the-css-box-model/
    2. w3schools: http://www.w3schools.com/css/css_boxmodel.asp
  4. Positioning: relative, absolute, fixed
    1. http://blog.teamtreehouse.com/css-positioning
    2. http://www.w3schools.com/css/css_positioning.asp
    3. http://alistapart.com/article/css-positioning-101
  5. Cascading Style Sheets – Inheritance
    1. i would read the section in head first for this
    2. http://www.webdesignfromscratch.com/html-css/css-inheritance-cascade/
  6. Type of elements
    1. read section in head first
    2. http://www.w3schools.com/css/css_display_visibility.asp
    3. http://www.webdesignfromscratch.com/html-css/css-block-and-inline/

These above are simply reference sources and will help you make more sense of things as you begin building your site and playing with the development tools.

After you have the above guides and bookmarks you will need the following tools:

  1. Google Chrome – this has the best developer tools of any web browser
  2. Sublime 2 Text Editor - this is where you will write code
  3. Twitter Bootstrap: just click "download bootstrap" for now.  For later projects you can find other themes, grid systems, and/or resets to start from.  No reason to reinvent the wheel.

At this point lets get a Hello World up…

Unzip the twitterboostrap zip file and open the file in sublime text. Open sublime > File > Open > Find folder and click open.

Copy and past this code into the blank file in sublime:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<title>Bootstrap 101 Template</title>
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<!-- Bootstrap -->
<link href="css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet" media="screen">
</head>
<body>
<h1>Hello, world!</h1>
<script src="http://code.jquery.com/jquery.js"></script>
<script src="js/bootstrap.min.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

Save it (cmd + s) as index.html inside the bootstrap folder.  Screen should now look like this.

Now right click on the index.html document and click reveal in finder.  From reveal in finder right click on index.html and open with > google chrome.  You’re document should open and look like this:

Now lets add a Nav Bar:

Add this to code to your index.html, save and reload page.

<div class="navbar">
<div class="navbar-inner">
<a class="brand" href="index.html">My First Website</a>
<ul class="nav">
<li class="active"><a href="#">Home</a></li>
<li><a href="#">About Me</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>

Your index.html doc should look like this:

And your site should look like this:

Now lets add a big Intro and Call-To section:

Add this code

<div class="container">

<div class="hero-unit">
<h1>Hello, world!</h1>
<p>This is a page header area. Link them here to a page about you.</p>
<p><a href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-large">Learn more about me »</a></p>
</div>

</div>

Your site should look like this

Unto the grid system and adding a new row with 3 elements:

Now we’re going to learn how the grid system works.  Here’s a quick run down on bootstrap’s grid system.  We’re going to add 3 different elements across the page.

Add this code.  Note that each of the three elements are of equal width so they each have a span4 class.

<div class="row">
 <div class="span4">
 <h2>Element 1</h2>
 <p>Donec id elit non mi porta gravida at eget metus. Fusce dapibus, tellus ac cursus commodo, tortor mauris condimentum nibh, ut fermentum massa justo sit amet risus. Etiam porta sem malesuada magna mollis euismod. Donec sed odio dui. </p>
 </div>
 <div class="span4">
 <h2>Element 2</h2>
 <p>Donec id elit non mi porta gravida at eget metus. Fusce dapibus, tellus ac cursus commodo, tortor mauris condimentum nibh, ut fermentum massa justo sit amet risus. Etiam porta sem malesuada magna mollis euismod. Donec sed odio dui. </p>
 </div>
 <div class="span4">
 <h2>Element 3</h2>
 <p>Donec sed odio dui. Cras justo odio, dapibus ac facilisis in, egestas eget quam. Vestibulum id ligula porta felis euismod semper. Fusce dapibus, tellus ac cursus commodo, tortor mauris condimentum nibh, ut fermentum massa justo sit amet risus.</p>
 </div>
 </div>

So here's what your code should look like:

And here's what your site should look like:

Finally, linking to another page

Let’s create that about me page we have on the top nav bar.  In sublime click File > New File.

Add this code:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
 <head>
 <title>Bootstrap 101 Template</title>
 <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
 <!-- Bootstrap -->
 <link href="css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet" media="screen">
 </head>
 <body>
<div class="navbar">
 <div class="navbar-inner">
 <a class="brand" href="index.html">My First Website</a>
 <ul class="nav">
 <li><a href="index.html">Home</a></li>
 <li class="active"><a href="about.html">About Me</a></li>
 <li><a href="#"></a></li>
 </ul>
 </div>
 </div>
<div class="container">
<p>
 This is your about me page. Now try other things out
 </p>
</div>
<script src="http://code.jquery.com/jquery.js"></script>
 <script src="js/bootstrap.min.js"></script>
 </body>
</html>

And save as about.html in the same folder you saved the index.html file.

Reopen the index.html file and edit the hero-unit div to say this:

<div class="hero-unit">
 <h1>Hello, world!</h1>
 <p>This is a page header area. Link them here to a page about you.</p>
 <p><a href="about.html" class="btn btn-primary btn-large">Learn more about me »</a></p>
 </div>

Also edit the navbar div to be this:

<div class="navbar">
 <div class="navbar-inner">
 <a class="brand" href="index.html">My First Website</a>
 <ul class="nav">
 <li class="active"><a href="index.html">Home</a></li>
 <li><a href="about.html">About Me</a></li>
 <li><a href="#"></a></li>
 </ul>
 </div>
 </div>

Now refresh the index page and click on the “about me” link in your nav bar or the “learn more about me” button on the page. You should see this:

Another fast feedback loop

 So you already see how to get feedback from your changes in code by opening your index.html document (or any html document) in your browser.  You can instantly see what your coding changes have done.  Here’s another way to test css and html changes in real time so you can start experimenting, learning, and building faster.

How to use the google developer tools.

  1. here is the documentation: https://developers.google.com/chrome-developer-tools/
  2. here is a quick tutorial: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nOEw9iiopwI
    1. literally only watch the first 50 seconds.  past that you will get confused.  From the first 50 seconds use the elements tab to highlight different elements and changing their style on the right side of the elements section.

Here’s an example of me changing our header section’s background to magenta. Notice how background-color is now set to #EAE.  I did this by highlighting <div classs=”hero-unit”> on the left and then double clicking on #EEE after background-color.  This is without changing any code in sublime.  Its strictly a way to see how changes you may want to make in the css will look on the site.

Next Steps and other things to try

1.  Read the twitter bootstrap documentation and now that you know how to use the developer tools and get fast feedback play around with it.

2.  To get started with one of the templates on the bootstrap’s “getting started” page.  Click on the template you like.  Then right click on page and click “view page source. “ Copy everything in between the two <body> tags and paste them inside the body tags in your index file.

Once you are satisfied with your site.  Here are the following steps with links to tutorials I think suffice

  1. Buy a domain name and hosting: http://www.killersites.com/articles/articles_liveOnTheWeb.htm
    1. note: I would use dream host, when you purchase your first year of hosting you get a free domain
    2. Download an ftp client and push the files to the server so they will be live on the web
      1. http://wiki.dreamhost.com/Building_A_Website

Once you have done this your first site is now live, up and running!  Congratulations

Why I suggest this path

Everything I’m about to say is expanded upon in the first 3 chapters of “The First 20 Hours” (a book that will change your life).

  1. We eliminate what is not essential.  Web development has been going on for years and there are experts that have crafted beautiful themes and systems to streamline the development process.  We’re piggybacking one of the most popular ones – Twitter Bootstrap – so we can get wins in the beginning.  You will be more excited to continue learning as you constantly see process and what your changes do.  There is no reason to reinvent the wheel and start from scratch.  You can do that later if you want.  I don’t think you will very often.
  2. You are forced to dive in over your head.  You could sit there and read book after book –we’ll call that learning- and never get to actually acquiring your new skill.  Or you can do this process and get your hands dirty now.
  3. You are being specific to the project that you want to achieve and cutting the fat.  Through this you stick to the essentials and see that web development is actually not as intimidating as you once initially thought.

You now have all the building blocks of front-end web development, the confidence, know-how and excitement to try new things, and will soon be a web development ninja.

Happy developing!

P.S.  Please leave comments and questions. Or if you are an experienced web developer what other competing methods or tutorials you think will benefit any one reading this?

P.P.S You're cool. Want to receive updates of my super awesome writings on online education and learning?

You're awesome.  Only the coolest stuff on the way.

item.title: Key to happy development and successful development
item.content:encoded:
picture of a funny contraption: thinking about something regarding a toilet and a kid; or a redneck and something; or maybe the carboard box project from Chik-fil-a (can throw in the funny one before the end quote from 37signals getting real about this subject

- Solve your own problems

- create things that you care about and are meaning ful to you

- if it solves a problem for you more than likely it will solve a problem for other people

- and if it doesn't it still wasn't a waste of time because it solved a problem for you (intrinsic value) and you learned something along the way I'm sure

- add examples of this

  1. basecamp
  2. asana

item.title: What are the characteristics of a successful entrepreneur
item.content:encoded:
Look at the common characteristics of successful entrepreneurs and create a skillset from them and give recommendations for courses

Ex of skills

Testing/analytical minded/data driven

Strong networks

Can create in mediums - know how to build things online today

Self-promoting

Bring Value

Ex of people

Tim Ferriss

Noah Kagan

Edison

How can I make this article timeless
item.dc:creator: rbonhardt@gmail.com

item.title: Creating course maps in school
item.content:encoded:
Hated learning history because I didn't know what the hell it had to do with real life.  Need to connect history lessons to real life.  

Talk tonight from Karl Smith from Engen works got me thinking when he made all these connections from history with Apachee Indians to studying animals with the apes to the spider, etc.

This is how school should be.  What is hte purpose of education
item.dc:creator: rbonhardt@gmail.com

item.title: Commonlog of Quotes
item.content:encoded:
From Ryan Holiday: "Montaigne kept what was known as a “commonplace book” or a hand-written compilation of sayings, maxims and quotations from literature and history that he felt were important. His earliest essays were little more than compilations of these thoughts." I agree.

On Life

Everyday should have some Novelty, Beauty, Growth, & Love. --Neville Medhora

Think good and it will be good. --Rabbi M. M. Schneerson

It's important to realize our time is limited on earth. --Noah Kagan

On (Making Money) Following Your Passion

Personally I’ve always made the most money when I created products, services or events that I loved and wanted to attend. When I reversed the equation and focused on how to make more money, it was always short-lived and not enjoyable. -- Noah Kagan

On Goals

“Thought is the sculptor who can create the person you want to be… In the long run, men hit only what they aim at.” --Henry David Thoreau, 19th century American naturalist and author

“The world makes way for the man who knows where he is going.” -- Ralph Waldo Emerson

“Give me a stock clerk with a goal and I’ll give you a man who will make history. Give me a man with no goals and I’ll give you a stock clerk.” -- JC Penny

“First say to yourself what you would be; and then do what you have to do.” -- Epictetus

“If one does not know to which port he is sailing, no wind is favorable.” -- Seneca

“You got to be careful if you don’t know where you’re going, because you might not get there.” -- Yogi Berra

On Patience

Learning that sharpening the saw first, is one of the MOST important parts of cutting down a tree.  – Neville medhora

On Play

On Sales

The next time you really want someone to understand, buy what you are selling or be convinced of your opinion figure out how you can show them vs tell them. – Noah Kagan

Like This Page? Why Not Share It?
